page.title: 08HISTORY
page.content:
The area was occupied by ancient man. There is a Bronze Age bell barrow (a type of burial mound) at 828586.
The Minley area is popularly associated with the notorious Captain Blood of Charles I's reign (see INNS).
{Minley Manor}is a house of historical interest. It was built in the 1860s by Raikes Currie, a wealthy banker. He built it in a French chateau style. Substantial alterations were made in the 1890s. The landscaped grounds include the spectacular Wellingtonia and Lime Avenue, 500 yards long. The War Office bought the Minley estate in 1936. Today it is occupied by the Royal Engineers. Public access is normally limited to the annual events of the Fete and Extravaganza.
